abstracts.cdata!:
The Land Management and Conservation
            Project was achieved. Implementation of the project, was
            fraught with problems almost from the onset. With little
            movement on the ground, by the end of 1992 it became
            apparent that there were major problems of communication and
            coordination between the two ministries. Efforts to
            restructure project management in 1993 to provide for
            greater autonomy of action, and budgets, for the Ministries
            of Agriculture (MOA) were to no avail. Throughout the period
            of implementation, Lesotho went through periods of political
            instability due to events both endogenous and exogenous (in
            particular the momentous changes occurring in the Republic
            of South Africa). This instability affected project
            implementation through changes in governmental structures
            and the ability to take consistent decisions regarding the
            role of chiefs and the powers of the Development Councils,
            as well as amendments to land legislation. In the last years
            of the project, the resurgence of democracy brought to the
            local level a new factionalism based on political
            affiliation. Any assessment of project implementation must
            take into account the underlying political conditions
            prevailing in Lesotho.
